DOC.HEAD: Bank of New England Rescinds Stock Dividend
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp., which expects heavy losses due to bad real estate loans, on Friday rescinded a common stock dividend it had declared last month. The announcement came one week after Bank of New England said it would boost its loan reserves above $1 billion and that it expected a ``substantial'' loss for the year. At the time, the bank also said it was exploring the sale or merger of its assets and was considering rescinding a 34 cents per share dividend for the fourth quarter ending Dec. 31. In a brief statement late Friday, the bank said its board of directors had agreed to rescind the dividend. Analysts said such action is highly unusual but reflects the serious trouble Bank of New England faces due to a real estate slump that has battered many of the region's banks. ``We're looking at a real estate market that is deteriorating very rapidly and very dramatically, and Bank of New England is a major real estate player,'' said James Moynihan, senior vice president of Advest Inc. in Boston. While 28 banks in New England have eliminated or cut dividends since April, Moynihan said: ``I've never seen a cash dividend declared, then rescinded.'' Bank of New England, the region's second largest bank, has come under increased scrutiny by regulators, and analysts predict changes could be forthcoming in the company's management. The bank last week reassigned a senior executive overseeing its real estate group. Moynihan also said the possibility is growing the bank could be acquired by an another bank or outside investor. ``One of the things you have to address is customer confidence,'' he said, noting the bank could have trouble restoring credibility without outside help.
